18/04/22    DHA â free tests for certain categories  As per the Dubai Health Authority (DHA), COVID-19 test is free only for the following categories:    â¢ UAE Nationals  â¢ Son / Daughter of UAE National mother  â¢ Households of UAE Nationals  â¢ Senior citizens & Residents (above the age of 50)  â¢ Pregnant women  â¢ People of determination (not their Families if residents)  â¢ Patients with chronic diseases: âDiabetes, hypertension, heart disease, arteries, tumors and rheumatism, chronic liver and kidney disease, brain and nerves (with condition of medical report)    Free test is provided every four months unless the patient develops COVID-19 symptoms, is in contact with a positive case or has developed a risk :pregnancy / chronic disease.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418170428/https://gulfnews.com/living-in-uae/health/looking-for-a-cheap-pcr-test-in-the-uae-here-are-all-your-options-1.1641395533878

The Government of Bahrain (GOB) has implemented enhanced screening measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19. Travelers should be prepared for travel restrictions to be put into effect with little or no advance notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425194439/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There is comprehensive public campaigns through media and government website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425194439/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
COVID-19 tests through the 444 hotline are free for citizens and residents of Bahrain.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425194439/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
All arrivals to Bahrain must activate the 'BeAware Bahrain' application.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220318125710/https://www.bahrainairport.bh/covid-19-travel-information

Mask wearing is now optional in both indoor and outdoor areas.  According to the National Medical Taskforce, mask wearing is encouraged when in the company of high-risk individuals and those with chronic health conditions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425194439/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Citizens and residents of Bahrain can now register for the Pfizer-BioNTech, Sinopharm, AstraZeneca, or Sputnik V COVID-19 vaccines on the Ministry of Healthâs website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220425194439/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Bahrain has launched mobile units providing home vaccinations against COVID-19 for the elderly and people with special needs. Bahrainâs official news agency BNA said that the service is the first of its kind in the region and is offered by medical teams who make home visits to the people who cannot make it to the vaccination centres and give them the jabs.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210406052034/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/bahrain/bahrain-launches-mobile-covid-19-vaccination-service-1.76481985

Travellers entering the country must show a negative negative COVID-19 PCR test 72 hours prior entering the country; and will be tested up arrival.  "All passengers over the age of 11 leaving or entering Djibouti, including those who have been vaccinated, must show a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours of boarding any flight bound for Djibouti and not more than 120 hours prior to their arrival at Ambouli International Airport (JIB). All travelers entering the country will also be tested for COVID-19 upon arrival and must wait at the port of entry until the results become available."    https://web.archive.org/web/20220216120454/https://crisis24.garda.com/alerts/2022/01/djibouti-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-travel-restrictions-as-of-jan-17-update-23

The Government of Djibouti offers COVID-19 tests at King Fahd and has a pop-up site near the Treasury. While the test itself is free, a negative COVID-19 test certificate costs 5,000 Fdj or $30. Additionally, you may pay 5,000 Fdj to request a test be conducted at your residence. Test results are delivered by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220101162250/https://covid19.gouv.dj/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220101161354/https://dj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220101161426/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/557591/djibouti-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-domestic-and-international-travel-restrictions-as-of-dec-17-update-2

-Being fully vaccinated is a prerequisite for attending classes for students and teachers.  -Health protocols call for mandatory masks, disinfected spaces and teams to monitor developments at schools, but not for increased physical distancing in classes.  -Three groups of students are now allowed to be absent from physical classrooms: those suffering from underlying conditions, those infected with coronavirus and those showing symptoms.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430124106/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2022/4/3/iran-fully-reopens-schools-after-two-years-as-ramadan-begins

Travel in Iran  -Measures and restrictions are in place in Iran, including temporary closure of non-essential businesses and shrines, and cancellation of some public events. Each province is able to introduce restrictions to respond to localised peaks in infections. This may include lockdown and restriction of movement, and may be introduced with little warning.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121640/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus    Are businesses and attractions open in Iran?  -Non-essential businesses and attractions are closed in high-risk areas, and a full lockdown is in place.  -There are some restrictions on unvaccinated individuals.  Are restaurants and bars open in Iran?  -Restaurants, cafes and bars are closed in high-risk areas.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121918/https://www.coronatestcentre.com/destinations/iran

-Non-essential businesses and attractions are closed in high-risk areas, and a full lockdown is in place.  -There are some restrictions on unvaccinated individuals.  -Large events such as concerts and sports matches remain either cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121918/https://www.coronatestcentre.com/destinations/iran

Dr. Hamid Reza Jamaati at the end of the meeting of the Scientific Committee for Iran's National Task Force for Fighting Coronavirus which was held this morning at the Heart Hotel in Tehran, in an exclusive interview with Iran Press News Agency added: "Necessary warnings should be given about Yalda night and the family gatherings so that Iranian citizens do not get involved in the coronavirus and especially the new Omicron variant."  *no new updates since 19 Dec 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430130538/https://iranpress.com/content/52494/omicron-enters-iran-iran-considers-4-week-nationwide-lockdown

Is public transportation open in Iran?  -Public transportation in Iran is operating, however travel to and from high-risk areas is banned.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121918/https://www.coronatestcentre.com/destinations/iran

The national anti-coronavirus task force said last month that a nighttime curfew for vehicles has been scrapped after much deliberation as it was deemed not effective enough.  *published on 06 Dec 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430120435/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/12/6/iran-imposes-restrictions-on-unvaccinated-in-new-covid-plan    Movement Restrictions:  Is a curfew in place? No  *written on 09 Dec 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430115231/https://ir.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    *no new updates

Travel in Iran  -It is now mandatory to wear face masks in enclosed public places. You may incur a fine if you do not comply.  -Measures and restrictions are in place in Iran, including temporary closure of non-essential businesses and shrines, and cancellation of some public events. Each province is able to introduce restrictions to respond to localised peaks in infections. This may include lockdown and restriction of movement, and may be introduced with little warning.  -Internal travel restrictions, including to important tourism and pilgrimage areas, may be imposed at short notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121640/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus

General  -Iran's borders remain closed, while some domestic restrictions are being lifted.    Can I Travel to Iran?  -Iran's borders are closed for travelers. Vaccinated travelers from safe countries can enter.  -Flights from countries considered high-risk are suspended.  -Foreign travelers must be fully vaccinated prior to traveling to Iran.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121918/https://www.coronatestcentre.com/destinations/iran

Key measures of the 2020 package included (i) extra funding for the health sector (2 percent of GDP); (ii) cash transfers to vulnerable households (0.5 percent of GDP); (iii) support to the unemployment insurance fund (0.3 percent of GDP); and (iv) subsidized loans for affected businesses and vulnerable households (4.7 percent of GDP). In addition, the government announced a moratorium on tax payments for a period of three months through June 2020 (6 percent of GDP). Sukuk bonds, the National Development Fund, and privatization proceeds provided part of the financing.  *As of 01 July 2021 - no new updates since  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430123411/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Central Bank of Iran has (i) announced the allocation of funds to import medicine; (ii) agreed  with commercial banks that they postpone by three months the repayment of loans due in February 2020; (iii) offered temporary penalty waivers for customers with non-performing loans; and (iv) expanded  contactless payments and increased the limits for bank transactions in order to reduce the circulation of banknotes and the exchange of debit cards.The Central Bank of Iran also reduced reserve requirements between April and September 2020 for commercial banks to boost lending to affected people and businesses.  *As of 01 July 2021 - no new updates since  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430123411/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Government of the Muslim Republic of Iran maintains a website that gives daily update about COVID-19 cases.     Ministry of Health and Medical Education:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430104549/https://irangov.ir/ministry-of-health-and-medical-education/1

COVID-19 Testing:  -Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Iran? Yes  -If so, are test results reliably available within 24 hours? Yes  -Free PCR tests may be obtained for symptomatic persons by dialing 4030 or 190. The Ministry of Health and Medical Education has allocated centers nationwide for this purpose.  -Hospitals, laboratories, and medical facilities that offer private PCR tests, the cost of which is borne by the individual.  The average cost of a PCR test is 2.5 â 3.5 million IRR. Most facilities offer testing at home and charge an additional average of 1.5 â 2 million IRR for the service.  As of 09 Dec 2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430115231/https://ir.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Quarantine requirements  People testing positive for COVID-19 may be required to isolate for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430115859/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/entry-requirements

It also said penalties have been considered for infected citizens who exit their homes during the period of their illness. It remains unclear how those patients are to be monitored â as Iran does not engage in widespread contact tracing â and how high the fines will be.  As of 06 Dec 2021  *No new updates  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430120435/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/12/6/iran-imposes-restrictions-on-unvaccinated-in-new-covid-plan

Travel in Iran  -It is now mandatory to wear face masks in enclosed public places. You may incur a fine if you do not comply.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121640/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/iran/coronavirus    Do I need to wear a face mask in Iran?  -Wearing a face mask is required in enclosed public places and on public transport.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430121918/https://www.coronatestcentre.com/destinations/iran    All passengers arriving into Iran need to wear a mask on the plane and in the airport at all times.  All passengers need to fill in a Passenger Locator Form provided by the airline before landing.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430122127/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/iran/    Masks  -REQUIRED  -Wearing a mask over your nose and mouth is required in indoor areas of public transportation (including on airplanes) traveling into, within, or out of the United States and indoors in U.S. transportation hubs (including airports).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430122812/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/covid-3/covid-19-iran

"Dr. Kamal Heidari, Deputy Minister of Health of the Ministry of Health, Treatment and Medical Education of Iran in a press conference on Wednesday said: With the approval of the Minister of Health and the approval of the National Task Force Against Coronavirus, in the first phase, vaccination of the age group over nine years began and from today, the immunization of the age group over five years will start in the country. "    "Iran's Health Ministry approves vaccination of children between 5 to 10" (Iran Press, 9 February 2022)  *No new updates from previous entry.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430102946/https://iranpress.com/content/55314/iran-health-ministry-approves-vaccination-children-between
No new policies.  Ministry of Health and Medical Education:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220430104549/https://irangov.ir/ministry-of-health-and-medical-education/1

Guidance for educational institutes, clubs and youth movements  It is not required to test or fill out a health declaration before arriving at the educational institutions.     In case of close contact with a confirmed COVID case  It is not required to go into isolation after close contact with a confirmed case, except in the following cases:  â¢	Unvaccinated or non-infected student who has been in close contact with a household member who is a confirmed case will go into full isolation.  The isolation period can be reduced from day 5 after the last contact with the confirmed case, according to the isolation reduction guidance (if the student continues to reside with the confirmed case, the confirmed case's recovery day is day 1 of the isolation. If the student does not continue residing with the confirmed case, the day of last contact is day 1 of isolation).  â¢	A student who stays in isolation with a confirmed case who cannot stay in isolation alone, and continues to be in close contact with the confirmed case will go into full isolation.  Isolation can be reduced starting from day 5 after the last contact with the confirmed case, according to the isolation reduction guidance (the recovery day of the confirmed case is day 1 of isolation). Those who have recovered from COVID and were then in close contact with a confirmed case, provided no more than 60 days have passed since the receipt of the certificate of recovery - will not be required to go into isolation.  Isolation guidance for close contacts of a confirmed COVID case     If symptoms appear  â¢	Students experiencing fever of 38 degrees or above will take a PCR test or a rapid test at an authorized testing site and stay in isolation until receiving a negative test result or until 48 hours have passed with fever lower than 37.5 degress without use of fever reducers.  â¢	Students experiencing coughing or difficulty breathing are advised to take a COVID test. They are required to avoid going to school or crowded places until the symptoms are gone.    From guidelines that, for the most part, seem to have been superseded by the advice above.  Masking is required indoors from the 1st grade onward. In a class where one or more student is deaf or hard of hearing, staff members shall wear a transparent mask.    Sources:  https://archive.ph/cGguV [Guidance for educational institutes, clubs and youth movements]  https://archive.ph/e4jAF [Local Councils Traffic Light Model - from 28 February, but still current]

Guidance for educational institutes, clubs and youth movements  It is not required to test or fill out a health declaration before arriving at the educational institutions.     In case of close contact with a confirmed COVID case  It is not required to go into isolation after close contact with a confirmed case, except in the following cases:    â¢	Unvaccinated or non-infected student who has been in close contact with a household member who is a confirmed case will go into full isolation.    The isolation period can be reduced from day 5 after the last contact with the confirmed case, according to the isolation reduction guidance (if the student continues to reside with the confirmed case, the confirmed case's recovery day is day 1 of the isolation. If the student does not continue residing with the confirmed case, the day of last contact is day 1 of isolation).    â¢	A student who stays in isolation with a confirmed case who cannot stay in isolation alone, and continues to be in close contact with the confirmed case will go into full isolation.    Isolation can be reduced starting from day 5 after the last contact with the confirmed case, according to the isolation reduction guidance (the recovery day of the confirmed case is day 1 of isolation). Those who have recovered from COVID and were then in close contact with a confirmed case, provided no more than 60 days have passed since the receipt of the certificate of recovery - will not be required to go into isolation.  Isolation guidance for close contacts of a confirmed COVID case     If symptoms appear  â¢	Students experiencing fever of 38 degrees or above will take a PCR test or a rapid test at an authorized testing site and stay in isolation until receiving a negative test result or until 48 hours have passed with fever lower than 37.5 degrees without use of fever reducers.  â¢	Students experiencing coughing or difficulty breathing are advised to take a COVID test. They are required to avoid going to school or crowded places until the symptoms are gone.    From guidelines that, for the most part, seem to have been superseded by the advice above.  Masking is required indoors from the 1st grade onward. In a class where one or more student is deaf or hard of hearing, staff members shall wear a transparent mask.    Sources:  https://archive.ph/cGguV [Guidance for educational institutes, clubs and youth movements]  https://archive.ph/e4jAF [Local Councils Traffic Light Model - from 28 February, but still current]

International Travel - Isolation  All travellers arriving in Israel must go into isolation, regardless of their age including those considered vaccinated or recovered. Travellers are required to stay in isolation until receipt of a negative result on the PCR test performed upon entry to Israel or for 24 hours, whichever is earlier.    Those who were recognized in Israel as recovered and no more than 60 days have passed since the recovery, are exempt from isolation.    **Travel National Guidance**  General Guidance  â¢	Masking is required indoors  Complete guidance for travellers entering and leaving Israel    Entry to Israel  â¢	Before arrival in Israel, make sure that you are not denied air travel  â¢	For further information about testing and isolation, see the link    Leaving Israel  â¢	Before leaving Israel, make sure that you are not denied air travel  â¢	For further information about testing and isolation, see the link    Red Locations (Highest Risk)  â¢	For further information about testing and isolation, see the link    Orange Locations (At Risk)  â¢	For further information about testing and isolation, see the link    Yellow Locations (Low Risk)  â¢	For further information about testing and isolation, see the link    Sources:  https://archive.ph/6xE84 [Entry into Israel]  https://archive.ph/e4jAF [Local Councils Traffic Light Model - from 28 February, but still current]  https://archive.ph/uGthY [Routine During the COVID-19 Pandemic]

Effectively screening at border control until the test is returned valid - less than 24 hours - so logged as screening rather quarantine.    All travellers arriving in Israel must go into isolation, regardless of their age including those considered vaccinated or recovered. Travellers are required to stay in isolation until receipt of a negative result on the PCR test performed upon entry to Israel or for 24 hours, whichever is earlier.    Those who were recognized in Israel as recovered and no more than 60 days have passed since the recovery, are exempt from isolation.    Source: https://archive.ph/sGMJc

Ministry of Health press release recommending fourth dose for over 60s.    The data from Israel indicate: A fourth dose of vaccine 3 times improves the protection against serious illness among those aged 60 and over, compared with those vaccinated only for a third dose.    Source: https://archive.ph/4C9yI [Ministry of Health press release]
'Celebrate Seder night together, and stay healthy' guidelines.  'Before we meet - get vaccinated (especially those aged 60 and over) and tested'    Source:  https://archive.ph/3TdCn [press release]

**When to take a rapid test at an authorized site**  For those under the age of 60 and not belonging to at-risk groups:  â¢	72 hours after exposure to a confirmed COVID-19 case    Isolation info for those who had close contact with confirmed COVID-19 case  â¢	If you fever of 38 degrees and more  If you have fever - enter isolation until negative test result received or 48 hours passed after fever broke without use of fever reduction medicaments.    â¢	If there are symptoms  In case of coughing or difficulty breathing - it is recommended to do a test.    â¢	To reduce the isolation period  Non-vaccinated and non-infected individuals who went into isolation due to close contact with a confirmed COVID-19 household member, can take tests from day 5 since the last contact with the confirmed case.    â¢	Vaccinated or recovered caregivers for a confirmed case who is under the age of 12 or has difficulty caring for himself    â¢	Non-vaccinated or non-recovered living with a confirmed case     â¢	Prior to visiting health and welfare institutions:    When visiting health and welfare institutions (such as assisted living or nursing homes), non-vaccinated and non-recovered must present a negative result on a rapid test taken at an authorized site in the 24 hours prior to the visit. Vaccinated and recovered can be tested at an authorized site or take a home test and present a certificate attesting a negative result on that test (for children under the age of 3 - a test is not required prior to a visit).     When to take a home test  â¢	If you are a COVID-19 confirmed case  In order to exit after 5 isolation days, a home test should be taken on day 4  eve and on day 5 eve (positive test day being first day). you can end isolation if both test are negative, there are no symptoms 48 hours prior and you received a HMO recovery certificate. In order to be recognized as a confirmed case, a PCR test or a rapid test at a supervised site is required.     â¢	72 hours after exposure to COVID-19 confirmed case  It is advised to take a test 72 hours after exposure to a confirmed case. If the test result is positive, you will be required to take a rapid test at an authorized site in order to be recognized as a confirmed case and later as a recovered case.    â¢	If there are symptoms consistent with COVID-19  Vaccinated and recovered individuals not belonging to risks groups and exhibit coughing or difficulty breathing are advised to take a home test. Positive test result â take a rapid test at an authorized site in order to be recognized as a confirmed case and later as a recovered case.    Please note: Those with fever are required to go into isolation until receiving a negative result on a rapid test taken at an authorized site or until 48 hours have passed after the fever is reduced without use of fever reduction medicaments.  Isolation info for those with symptoms    Important: home tests cannot be used for isolation reduction for those who are not a confirmed case, or for being recognized as a confirmed case and later as recovered.    Source: https://archive.ph/TqCpT [Testing]

Morocco requires proof of vaccination to enter most private and public establishments, including hotels, restaurants, cafes, gyms, hammams, grocery stores, and public modes of transportation. If vaccinated in Morocco, U.S. citizens should carry the vaccine pass (âpass vaccinalâ) issued by the Moroccan government and available at the Ministry of Health vaccination website. If vaccinated in the United States, we recommend U.S. citizens carry their white CDC card as proof of vaccination. Additionally, U.S. citizens vaccinated in the United States may be able to access the Vaccination Administration Management System (VAMS) within the United States to obtain a QR code. At this time, we cannot be certain what proof will be accepted by individual establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222134405/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Those seeking to enter Morocco must:  Present a vaccination pass* (for those 12+  years of age), demonstrating that they have been fully vaccinated (at least two doses, unless the Johnson & Johnson vaccine was administered);    Present a negative PCR test taken less than 48 hours before boarding the plane (for those 7+ years of age);  Submit to rapid antigen testing upon arrival in Morocco; and  Submit â if requested â to random PCR testing (for those 7+ years of age) after entry into Morocco.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222134405/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Financial aides have been given from March to June. COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Morocco? Yes. Testing is available in major cities throughout Morocco.  The cost for a PCR test is typically around 400 Dirhams, though same-day test results may cost extra.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222134405/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No evidence for contact tracing found online.

"In addition, wearing a mask is compulsory throughout the Kingdom. Everyone is required to comply with the mandatory measures provided for in the context of the state of emergency under pain of penalties provided for in the penal code."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210329174433/https://ma.ambafrance.org/Coronavirus-Conditions-de-deplacement-Reponses-aux-principales-questions

COVID-19 Vaccine Information    Has the government of Morocco approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Morocco for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes  Which vaccines are available in Morocco?  Pfizer (U.S.), AstraZeneca (UK), Sinopharm (China), and Sputnik V (Russia)  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222134405/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No measures in place.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220222134405/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mask-wearing is no longer obligatory in schools, however is still recommended. Social distancing and cohorting is encouraged.     Source: https://deputyprimeminister.gov.mt/en/health-promotion/covid-19/Documents/Education%20Guidance%20April%202022_25_4.pdf

Parties and weddings can resume as normal - vaccine certificates no longer required for entry into parties etc    Source; http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

Standing events outdoors no longer require a vaccination certificate. However, indoor standing events still require a certificate.       Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220411065136/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/covid-self-testing-to-be-allowed-negative-pcr-test-for-red-list.945960

Weddings, parties and all other social activities can resume as normal.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

As from April 10, there will no longer be a capping on the number of people who can gather in crowds     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220411065136/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/covid-self-testing-to-be-allowed-negative-pcr-test-for-red-list.945960

PCR tests and recovery certificates will now be recognized for travel purposes. This means that Malta will no longer require travellers to be fully vaccinated but can now come to the island with a negative test or proof of infection in recent months. This is only eligible for those travelling from red list countries.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220420131455/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/covid-self-testing-to-be-allowed-negative-pcr-test-for-red-list.945960

PLF is no longer needed for travel to Malta. However, most travel rules have remained in place. Anyone arriving in Malta will still need to present either a vaccine certificate, negative PCR test or recovery certificate for entry. Red and dark red travel lists will also remain in place    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

Only those who test positive for COVID-19 will have to isolate. People who live with a COVID-19 patient no longer have to quarantine, unless they show symptoms of the virus. Primary contacts, even those unvaccinated, also no longer need to quarantine. Positive cases of COVID-19 must quarantine for 1 week, after which they can exit upon proof of a negative test, or remain in quarantine for 10 days total.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted#.YnJMfXbP02w

Masks are no longer required in schools as from 13th April. Now that the mask requirement in schools is to be dropped, mandatory mask wearing will only be needed in shops and other public indoor places.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220420131455/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/covid-self-testing-to-be-allowed-negative-pcr-test-for-red-list.945960

Masks are no longer mandatory in indoor public places such as shops, restaurants etc. Masks are only required on flights, inside hospitals, health clinics and care homes.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220504095049/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/116391/weddings_parties_back_to_normal_from_2_may_as_most_covid19_restrictions_are_lifted

In Gaza, there is a mandatory quarantine: 7 days for a negative COVID-19 test or 21 days with a positive COVID-19 test.    West Bank:   "- Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? [Yes]  - Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? [Yes]  - Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? [Yes] The Palestinian Authority requires all individuals who seek to enter the West Bank via the Allenby crossing to take a COVID -19 test within 72 hours."    Gaza:  "- Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter??[No]  - The de facto authority in Gaza stated that travel in and out of Gaza will only be permitted for urgent humanitarian cases through Erez and Rafah crossings and that those coming into Gaza will be required to take a COVID-19 test and quarantine for a mandatory period of seven days (with a negative COVID-19 test) or 21 days (with a positive COVID-19 test)."
